webTitle: Four tax inspectors pursuing HMRC's most wanted

fields.standfirst: Revelation of strategy over tax fugitives prompts Labour to accuse David Cameron of 'totally failing' to tackle tax avoidance
fields.body:
David Cameron has been accused of totally failing to tackle tax avoidance and tax evasion after official figures showed that just four inspectors are chasing 124 tax fugitives.

Shabana Mahmood, the shadow Treasury minister, said people would be astonished that such a lax approach was being adopted after the amount of uncollected tax rose last year.

Labour criticised the government after the Treasury minister, David Gauke, admitted in reply to a parliamentary written question that four employees of HMRC are working to capture 124 tax fugitives.

Gauke told Mahmood: "The HMRC fugitive unit team consists of one higher officer and two officers managed by one senior investigation officer. The Fugitive Unit liaise with the allocated HMRC officer (who has responsibility for the original investigation), sharing information to enable a fugitive to be located. When an extradition is arranged the team are able to call on a cadre of HMRC officers specifically trained to handle extraditions from overseas. The team focuses not only on the fugitives publicised in the most wanted campaign but also on all current HMRC fugitives. There are 124 HMRC fugitives.

The Fugitive Unit role is to review, trace and locate, and where possible extradite all current HMRC fugitives (including those featured in the Most Wanted campaign) and bring them before the UK court specified in the First Instance or Failure to Appear Warrant. HMRC staff (including the Fugitive Unit) use all available systems and resources to carry out this work. This includes working closely with HMRC's fiscal liaison officers based overseas, Crown Prosecution Service, National Crime Agency, Interpol and other international partners."

In a further parliamentary written reply, Gauke admitted that authorities do not know the whereabouts of 11 of the 32 most-wanted tax fugitives.

It says of the 11: "Proceedings not yet possible, as fugitive not located." Of the other 21, proceedings have started against seven, four have been arrested or convicted, proceedings were not possible against six because they could not be extradited, proceedings have been delayed in two cases because the host country does not extradite people for alleged tax offences, while two are awaiting a legal decision.

Mahmood said: "People will be astonished at the revelation that just four tax inspectors are chasing 124 tax fugitives despite George Osborne claiming this to be a priority. David Cameron's government is totally failing to tackle tax avoidance and evasion or give it the priority it needs. The amount of uncollected tax rose last year and the Swiss tax deal has raised just a fraction of the revenues promised.

"At a time when ordinary people are facing a cost-of-living crisis and the deficit is high this isn't good enough. It's no wonder the Public Accounts Committee has just issued such a damning report on the government's failure."

Earlier this year, the chancellor warned that tax evasion would not be tolerated as he released an updated gallery on the 30 most-wanted tax fugitives.

The chancellor said: "Our message is clear; tax fraud and evasion is illegal and will not be tolerated. Millions of hard-working people pay their taxes and it is they who are being defrauded.. The government has stepped up HMRC's enforcement activities to enable them to pursue tax cheats relentlessly around the world."

"The publication of HMRC's Most Wanted has already helped catch two people wanted for tax fraud. This new list will help put more tax fraudsters in the spotlight and bring them to justice."

Labour pointed out that the four officials dedicated to the tax fugitives compares with the 450 HMRC staff involved in administering the withdrawal of child benefit from higher-rate taxpayers.

fields.standfirst: The year delivered a strong crop of financial thrills and spills – but also posed a number of as yet unanswered questions
fields.body:
How is Twitter worth $40bn?

The microblogging site floated in November at $26 (£16) a share, or $17bn. The price seemed silly for a company that has never made a profit and is on course for revenues of only $600m this year. Yet the share price is now close to $70. Twitter is plainly a social phenomenon but has yet to show it can take a meaningful chunk of online advertising without infuriating users. The valuation of 60-times revenues is otherworldly; it may also be evidence that heavy doses of quantitative easing have messed up traditional investment radars.

Why was the Co-op Bank farce allowed to run for so long?

The Rev Paul Flowers, dubbed the "Crystal Methodist" after allegations of drug use, generated the bulk of the headlines. The mystery, however, is why regulators allowed a severely under-capitalised and under-managed Co-op Bank to try to buy 630 branches from Lloyds. The expedition was finally abandoned in April and a £1.5bn capital hole revealed soon afterwards. We are still awaiting a full explanation of why regulators didn't intervene earlier.

How did Help to Buy, mark two, ever get off the ground?

Arguably, the first version of the chancellor's housing scheme, confined to creditworthy first-time buyers, was semi-respectable. The second version, however, involves the state writing first-loss insurance on house purchases worth up to £600,000. Why? House prices are rising again – at an annual rate of 10% in London – and affordability is already stretched if historical price-to-earnings ratios are a guide. Meanwhile, the emergency Funding for Lending scheme for banks is being axed for mortgages. George Osborne is making it harder for the Bank of England to prevent a housing bubble.

Why isn't the growth of zero-hours contracts an election issue?

Flexibility in the labour force is an asset and some workers are clearly content with contracts that offer no guarantee of regular work. But, when 1 million people may be employed this way, a large swath of the UK workforce has been quietly casualised. In some cases, workers may be exploited by being denied holiday and sickness pay. The effect on productivity could be long-lasting. The lack of intensity in the political debate is mystifying.

How do investment banks continue to charge so much?

The question could be asked most years, but 2013 brought two startling examples. Barclays shelled out a colossal £130m in fees to other banks who took little real risk in underwriting a deeply discounted £6bn rights issue. And Severn Trent managed to clock up £19m in "advisory, legal and other services" in a single month in resisting a takeover approach that never became a formal bid. For comparison, it cost £4.8m to run the water company's board, comprising five executives and six non-executive directors, for a full year.

Is the eurozone crisis really over?

The Cyprus banks crisis was handled crassly at the start of the year. Since then, the wider eurozone crisis has seemed becalmed, despite the continued economic funk in euroland. Greece is still the country to watch. Deflation could quickly undermine the ambition of reducing public debt (now 170% of GDP) if nominal GDP grows only slowly. In that case, a third bailout, and write-offs of loans, may be required. That messy debate could again be alive this time next year.

Does GlaxoSmithKline have a future in China?

Back in July, when allegations of bribery and corruption were made against GSK's Chinese unit, a fine and a rapid restructuring of working practices seemed a likely outcome. Five months on, investigations continue, dozens of local employees remain in detention and chief executive Sir Andrew Witty has not been able to draw a line. He says there is "no question" about GSK's commitment to China. But the question of how the commitment is meant to be achieved is unresolved.

Can Ed Miliband's proposed freeze on energy bills be made credible?

The idea to cap fuel bills for 20 months is popular; it even prompted the government to make a minor tweak of green levies. But does a price freeze, regardless of what happens to the wholesale price of energy, stand any chance of working in practice? How would Labour oblige energy firms to invest in new infrastructure? Would firms really be allowed to set their own tariffs in the 21st month? The answer is supposed to be "yes" because the energy market would have been "re-set" in a fair and transparent way. That is ambitious, to put it mildly. The plan needs much more detail.

Is it safe to taper?

This is the big one for global markets. The US Federal Reserve has started to ease back on quantitative easing, even if the change of gears is hardly crunching – there will be a $10bn monthly reduction to $75bn. But the expectation of a full and gradual wind-down of asset purchases has been created. If the US recovery proves too weak to allow a full taper, the Fed is in trouble.

How does Jamie Dimon survive at JP Morgan?

The US bank paid a record $13bn to settle with the US justice department for mis-selling mortgage securities. There were also fines of $920m relating to the "London Whale" incident, which Dimon initially dismissed as a "tempest in a teapot" but which led to a $6bn loss. he Financial Conduct Authority saying it was "deliberately misled" by London-based executives on one occasion. Dimon, though, remains as chairman and chief executive of JP Morgan. Shareholders and regulators, bizarrely, continue to approve the concentration of power.

Does Labour really believe in HS2?

The proposed high-speed rail line had a bad year. The cost is now put at £50bn shadow chancellor Ed Balls said there should be "no blank cheque." If that is the prelude to a Labour retreat, HS2 must be heading for the sidings.

How did Dame Clara Furse get on to the financial policy committee?

Furse had a long and honourable innings as chief executive of the London Stock Exchange but this appointment was extraordinary as she was also an established non-executive director of Fortis when that financial institution had to be rescued by the Belgian government in 2008.

Why is the government still in denial about Royal Mail?

A 60% stake was sold at 330p in October. Now shares in the postal service trade at 580p. Spare us pleas about "froth" in the after-market and the need to attract long-term investors. Royal Mail's potential as a big dividend-payer was undersold and the shares were underpriced.

• This article was amended on 30 December 2013. The original suggested that zero hours contracts should be "an electric issue". This has been corrected.

webTitle: High street post-Christmas sales dampen as shoppers stay at home

fields.standfirst: Festive retail footfall stumbles nearly 5% as online shopping keeps consumers indoors and bad weather blows away hopes of last-minute spree
fields.body:
Retailers hoping for a steady boost from bargain hunters were disappointed on Friday when a strong start to the post-Christmas sales went into reverse.

The number of shoppers out and about fell 4.7% across the UK compared with the same day last year, according to retail data company Springboard, as storm warnings and wet weather, particularly in Scotland, deterred shoppers. It followed a 1.5% uplift on Boxing Day compared with 2012.

However, online retailers confirmed that sales remained strong, in further evidence of changing shopping habits – with greater numbers cherry-picking the best bargains online from the sofa.

High streets were particularly hard hit on Friday, recording a 13.9% slump in visitor numbers, while shopping centres were 1.9% down. Only out-of-town retail parks recorded a rise in visitors, up 2.3%.

"The surge on Boxing Day has had an impact on the following day," said Diane Wehrle, insights director at Springboard. She said the number of shoppers visiting stores across the UK was down 3% in the first three weeks in December. "Hopes of a last-minute buying spree were blown apart by the bad weather."

Even John Lewis, which doesn't open on Boxing Day, so that shoppers must wait until the 27th to bag bargains, suggested there had only been a slight uplift in sales on Friday compared with 2012. But the retailer continues to trade online and said there had been a surge in demand.

Paula Nickolds, buying and brand director for John Lewis, said: "More than ever, people are shopping in different ways with us, reflected in the massive 76% share of traffic to johnlewis.com that came from mobile devices on Christmas Day."

The Bullring shopping centre in Birmingham, meanwhile, welcomed about 150,000 visitors compared with 200,000 on Boxing Day, although the centre was still busy with queues outside some stores, including US teen brand Hollister.

It was a different story for online retailers, where sales appeared to build momentum. "The weather is helping online players. People are staying at home with their turkey leftovers, shopping from home," said Jonathan Brown, chief executive of clothing website M&M Direct.

Several retailers confirmed that momentum was building online. B&Q said online sales rose 69% on Boxing Day and 86% on Friday while M&M Direct also reported a double-digit spike in sales on Boxing Day compared with last year and an improvement on Friday.

Total online sales on Boxing Day rose 40.4% from last year, according to IBM Digital Analytics, which tracks millions of online transactions. Sales on mobile devices outstripped sales via PCs for the first time.

Dixons, the owner of Currys and PC World, said it had recorded a 16% year-on year increase in website traffic from the start of its sale on Christmas Eve until midnight on Christmas Day.

Jeremy Fennell, e-commerce director at Dixons, said: "British shoppers are savvier than ever, using Christmas Eve and Christmas Day to get the jump on Boxing Day sales."

Clothing retailers said that shoppers were using the internet to ensure they bagged the items they wanted after having tried them on in stores.

That's bad news for fashion stores, which have had a difficult end to the year as the mild weather, a squeeze on shoppers' disposable income and competition from tempting and pricey gifts such as games consoles and tablet computers have hit sales.

One industry insider suggested that the British clothing market was down as much as 3% year on year in December, although some retailers have managed to preserve or even lift profits by keeping stocks tight and holding back on discounts. He said: "The last-minute rush hasn't made up for a difficult season."

webTitle: House of Fraser flotation rocked by troubled Christmas run-in

fields.standfirst: Department store's long-desired return to stock market in new year may suffer among glut of potential launches, say analysts
fields.body:
House of Fraser's chances of pulling off a return to the stock market in the new year could be hit by difficult trading for clothing specialists and department stores before Christmas.

The retailer was among the heaviest discounters as Christmas approached, with shoppers leaving their gift-buying late and holding back on purchasing warm weather gear.

House of Fraser's prospects may also be affected by the tribulations of its fellow department store Debenhams. The listed retailer has also been discounting heavily and a hamfisted attempt to protect profit margins by writing to suppliers for a 2.5% discount just before Christmas prompted analysts to downgrade profits and its share price to slide.

The fallout puts further pressure on the letter's author – the finance director, Simon Herrick – after a series of unexpected blows to profits in 2013. Debenhams' board of directors will decide on his future in the new year.

Nick Bubb, a veteran retail analyst, said: "I never thought a House of Fraser IPO had much of a chance and it looks even less likely now."

Owners of the chain, led by the chairman, Don McCarthy, whose family holds a 20% stake, have been searching for more than a year for a way to offload the debt-laden business, which has a large pension deficit. The financial advisory group Rothschild has been hired to advise on a float but the owners are also in talks with Galeries Lafayette, the French department store, which has the right to exclusive discussions until the end of January.

McCarthy is thought to be hoping for a valuation of between £350m and £450m, flagging up the company's strong online sales and potential for overseas growth. But House of Fraser has struggled to make a profit after servicing its £250m debt.

Tony Shiret, an analyst at Espirito Santo, said: "Weak trade and oversupply of IPOs is going to favour the better quality opportunities, more reasonably priced."

House of Fraser is among a clutch of retailers considering launching on the stock market in 2014. With equity valuations high and hopes of a consumer recovery in the air, private equity owners see a chance to offload retail businesses before they see an uptick in interest rates that could increase the cost of their debt.

The successful flotation of Conviviality Retail, owner of the Bargain Booze chain in the summer, and Bonmarché, the fashion chain, last month have also encouraged other retailers to consider the leap.

Convenience store operator McColl's, specialist retailers Pets at Home and Card Factory, internet pure players The Hut, and Appliances Online, low-price operators Poundland and B&M Bargains, furniture chain DFS, and fashion retailer Fat Face are all thought to be looking at IPOs.

Several commentators suggested that with as many as 16 retailers considering a stock market flotation in 2014, half of those might fail to get off the ground. One adviser, who declined to be named, said: "They won't all get away. As investors know so many are coming to the market, they will be quite choosy."

While Poundland, Appliances Online and Pets at Home are widely expected to float in the first three months of the new year, there are already signs that the difficult autumn trading is having an effect on IPOs. Boohoo.com, the privately owned young fashion retailer, had been expected to launch this autumn, although it is now thought likely to make its move in the new year. One source said the delay was down to meagre investor interest.

Owners of the chain, led by the chairman, Don McCarthy, whose family holds a 20% stake, have been searching for more than a year for a way to offload the debt-laden business, which has a large pension deficit. The financial advisory group Rothschild has been hired to advise on a float but the owners are also in talks with Galeries Lafayette, the French department store, which has the right to exclusive discussions until the end of January. McCarthy is thought to be hoping for a valuation of between £350m and £450m, flagging up the company's strong online sales and potential for overseas growth. But House of Fraser has struggled to make a profit after servicing its £250m debt. Tony Shiret, an analyst at Espirito Santo, said: "Weak trade and oversupply of IPOs is going to favour the better quality opportunities, more reasonably priced." House of Fraser is among a clutch of retailers considering launching on the stock market in 2014. With equity valuations high and hopes of a consumer recovery in the air, private equity owners see a chance to offload retail businesses before they see an uptick in interest rates that could increase the cost of their debt. The successful flotation of Conviviality Retail, owner of the Bargain Booze chain in the summer, and Bonmarché, the fashion chain, last month have also encouraged other retailers to consider the leap. Convenience store operator McColl's, specialist retailers Pets at Home and Card Factory, internet pure players The Hut, and Appliances Online, low-price operators Poundland and B&M Bargains, furniture chain DFS, and fashion retailer Fat Face are all thought to be looking at IPOs. Several commentators suggested that with as many as 16 retailers considering a stock market flotation in 2014, half of those might fail to get off the ground. One adviser, who declined to be named, said: "They won't all get away. As investors know so many are coming to the market, they will be quite choosy." While Poundland, Appliances Online and Pets at Home are widely expected to float in the first three months of the new year, there are already signs that the difficult autumn trading is having an effect on IPOs. Boohoo.com, the privately owned young fashion retailer, had been expected to launch this autumn, although it is now thought likely to make its move in the new year. One source said the delay was down to meagre investor interest.
fields.headline: House of Fraser flotation rocked by troubled Christmas run-in
fields.trailText: Department store's long-desired return to stock market in new year may suffer among glut of potential launches, say analysts

webTitle: FTSE hits best level since early November on US optimism and Chinese bank moves

fields.bodyText: Despite the trading week being curtailed for some holiday or other, leading shares continued on their merry way to their best annual performance since 2009, with analysts predicting a new record for the FTSE 100 next year. The index finished at 6750.87 yesterday, up 56.70 points on the day and 144 points on the week albeit amid thin dealing volumes. This was its sixth day of rises, its longest winning streak since the middle of October and its best level since 4 November. Investors are becoming increasingly convinced that the US economy will continue to move ahead in the coming months, despite the US Federal Reserve's recent decision to start turning off the money taps which have been such a key support for the markets. This week's US data helped the positive mood, with strong durable goods orders and a bigger than expected fall in weekly jobless figures. Recent fears of a credit crunch in China were eased by the People's Bank of China injecting liquidity into the market. The leading index is currently up more than 14% on the year, compared to a 22% rise in 2009. In the intervening years, it rose 5.84% in 2012, lost 5.55% in 2011 and rose 9% in 2010. But unlike the leading US markets, the Nikkei and Germany's Dax, the FTSE 100 is still well below its all time closing high (the 6930 level reached in December 1999) so analysts believe the index is likely to advance further next year. Goldman Sachs expects the FTSE 100 to reach 7500 by the end of 2014 while analysts at Killik & Co have a target of 7400. Killik said: We expect equities to enjoy another good year, driven by above-average growth in the US and stabilisation in the eurozone and China. Although there are still risks, ongoing loose monetary policy continues to highlight the relative yield attraction of equities, while M&A could be more of a supportive feature. BSkyB was one company reportedly in the sights of a possible predator. Vodafone was said be considering a bid as a tactic to fend off any approach for the mobile phone group from US rival AT&T. BSkyB shares moved sharply higher on the tale, adding another 11.5p to 844.5p on Friday. Vodafone rose 1.55p to 237.95p. With China saying its industrial output was likely to have grown by 9.8% in 2013, and fears of a credit crunch in the country easing, commodity companies were among the leading gainers on Friday. David Madden, market analyst at IG, said: Overnight the People's Bank of China made a cash injection into the interbank market in order to increase liquidity, driving the borrowing costs for Chinese banks to its biggest weekly drop since 2011. China is a major importer of minerals, and traders bought natural resource stocks as they felt a more robust interbank market would ensure domestic companies would be able to continue their high levels of business activity. So Glencore Xstrata climbed 7.65p to 315.7p while Antofagasta added 25.5p to 830.5p and Mexican silver miner Fresnillo rose 25.5p to 735p. Elsewhere Arm closed 11p higher at £11.06, boosted by the week's news that one of its key customers, Apple, had signed a long awaited deal with China Mobile, giving it access to one of the world's fastest growing markets. Royal Mail added 1.5p to 580p on Friday but its first week as a member of the FTSE 100 saw it lose 11p as profit takers moved in. AstraZeneca dipped 7p to £36.05 as the pharmaceutical group settled a dispute with Japan's Shionogi over its cholosterol treatment Crestor and extended its licensing deal with the company from 2016 to 2013 but with a lower royalty rate in 2014. Lower down the market, Premier Foods had a roller coaster week, slumping 7% after it confirmed it was considering the possibility of a £300m rights issue, as part of a review of its capital structure. But on Friday it recovered 6.25p or 5% to 131p. Finally International Personal Finance saw its shares lose nearly 16% on Friday. The emerging markets lender announced on Christmas Eve that it had been fined £2.4m from the Polish consumer protection office over the way it calculated APR amounts. Analysts said the move could prove devastating for its business model, with Poland providing 45% of its profits. The company said it would appeal the decision, since it believed on legal advice it was correctly calculating the cost of credit. But it said it was not possible to estimate the impact a final negative ruling might have on its Polish business.

webTitle: Shops take stock of Christmas leftovers

fields.standfirst: Hard-to-eat gingerbread houses, 12 teas of Christmas and Heston Blumenthal mince pies among recent turkeys
fields.body:
They are known in the trade as Christmas turkeys – the festive food products imported or dreamed up by product development geeks to be seasonal "must haves", but which end up heavily discounted after failing to fly off the shelves.

In previous years shoppers have turned their noses up at hard-to-eat gingerbread houses (tough on the fillings), themed "12 teas of Christmas" and even Heston Blumenthal's mince pies with pine-infused sugar – which consumers complained had a whiff of toilet cleaner.

After the huge success of Heston's bestselling "hidden orange" Christmas pudding – so popular that some ended up on eBay – Waitrose launched the mince pies, which the chef declared were "delicious eaten warm from the oven and then sprinkled with pine sugar for a Christmas tree aroma". Consumers were not so sure. Although Waitrose said the pies were still for sale, huge quantities were discounted after Christmas last year.

Among the possible turkeys this year is a "Christmas dinner in a tin" sold by retailer Game, for gamers who planned on spending the entire festive period on their new consoles. The meal boasts nine layers – from a fry-up for breakfast through to turkey and veg, and even mince pies for dessert.

Retailers were understandably reluctant to reveal their most embarrassing Christmas flops, never mind the full scale of commercial disaster. But the luxury retailer Harrods admitted it got its fingers burned last year when it launched an own-brand "12 teas of Christmas" gift set. It was able to salvage the situation as the product was an "ambient" one, not fresh food with a limited shelf life.

Bruce Langlands, director of food and drink at Harrods, said: "We launched a Harrods 12 teas of Christmas gift set last year, which unfortunately did not sell very well. This year we have reworked the packaging design and displayed the product in a different area of the food hall and now it is a bestselling Christmas gift. Small changes can make a difference."

webTitle: 'Alice in Wongaland': business review of the year 2013 - in pictures

fields.standfirst: Five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers almost tipped the global economy into the abyss, recovery has been slow and halting. Meanwhile the UK's 'Alice in Wongaland' economy has been coasting on easy money, its growth propelled by shopping sprees and property prices. It was a phrase which struck a chord in a year when many things were not quite what they seemed

webTitle: International Personal Finance slumps by a fifth on Polish problems

fields.standfirst: Analysts say its business model could be hit by regulatory ruling on APR charges
fields.body:
International Personal Finance has seen its shares crash by more than a fifth after the emerging markets lender received an unwelcome Christmas gift from Poland.

The company announced on Christmas Eve that it had been fined £2.4m from the Polish consumer protection office over the way it calculated APR amounts. The authorities believed that the fee for an optional home collection service and a preparatory fee associated with this should be included in the APR amount.

Analysts said the move could prove devastating for its business model, with Poland providing 45% of its profits.

The company said it would appeal the decision, since it believed on legal advice it was correctly calculating the cost of credit. But it said it was not possible to estimate the impact a final negative ruling might have on its Polish business, and its shares have slumped 120p or 22% to 420p, making it the biggest faller in the FTSE 250. The outcome of any court decision could take months, and Gary Greenwood at Shore Capital said:

While the fine itself is not material, in our view, the proposed inclusion of the preparatory fee and home collection service charge in the APR calculation has potentially much wider implications. This is because the Polish regulator is proposing to introduce a 30% per annum cap on non-interest related credit costs. This is on top of an existing interest rate cap of 4 times the Lombard rate (currently equivalent to 16% per annum). If the revised APR calculation is imposed in Poland it could be potentially devastating for the company's business model in Poland, we think, as it would severely restrict the pricing structure. As Poland is IPF's largest profit centre, accounting for just over half of the group total, this is clearly a big issue.
Putting the shares on a ... 10 times PE (broadly in line with their historical 5-year average), would see them valued at around 400p, implying a further 25% or so downside. In addition, with a prospective dividend yield of less than 2%, there is little in the way of income support. It is therefore not too late to get out, in our view. Sell.

Numis analyst James Hamilton said:

This in itself does not materially concern us other than it is never good to be on the wrong side of the regulator. Of greater concern is the discussion paper which is looking at changing the interest rate cap to a cost of credit or APR cap. These two combined in a worst case scenario with a low APR cap could fundamentally impact the Polish business which accounts for 45% of IPF's profit. Given the lack of certainty we have moved our recommendation to under review [from hold].

webTitle: FTSE continues festive rally as Vodafone bid speculation continues

fields.standfirst: Mobile phone group reported as a possible predator for BSkyB to fend off AT&T
fields.body:
With leading shares on course for their best annual performance since 2009, BSkyB was in focus again.

Earlier in the week the satellite broadcaster was tipped in a report as a possible bid target for Vodafone. The idea was that the mobile phone group would take a tilt at BSkyB to help fend off a potential bid from US giant AT&T. Vodafone has been seen as vulnerable to a predator since it announced the sale of its stake in US joint venture Verizon Wireless.

Although very speculative, the tale has continued to push BSkyB higher, with its shares currently up 6.5p at 839.5p. Vodafone, meanwhile, is up 0.5p at 236.9p. Marc Kimsey, senior trader at Accendo Markets, said:

Traders are buying into the Vodafone-BskyB story and with good reason. A UK quad play opportunity for Vodafone will go some way to filling the void left by the Verizon Wireless disposal. The move will keep AT&T at arm's length but it needs to happen quickly, the US telecoms giant has been doing it's homework for some time, a first quarter advance cannot be ruled out.

Overall, the FTSE 100 is currently up 30.06 points at 6724.23, its best level since 18 November. The leading index is currently up around 14% on the year, compared to a 22% rise in 2009. In the intervening years, it rose 5.84% in 2012, lost 5.55% in 2011 and rose 9% in 2010.

With China saying its industrial output was likely to have grown by 9.8% in 2013, and fears of a credit crunch in the country easing, commodity companies were among the gains. Glencore Xstrata has added 4.95p to 313p while Mexican silver miner Fresnillo is up 12p at 721.5p.
